cleaned_text: HARNESSING THE POWER OF INNOVATION, HEALTH EQUITY, AND COMMUNITY TO END THE HIV EPIDEMIC #32YearsofCAREWELCOME LETTERS 2022 CONFERENCE THEME & GOALS CONTINUING EDUCATION AND MEETING EVALUATIONS CONFERENCE WORKSHOP TRACKS PLENARY SCHEDULE PLENARY SPEAKERS BUSINESS DAY MEETINGS AGENDA POSTER PRESENTATIONS EXHIBITORSTABLE OF CONTENTS 3 5 6 11 13 15 26 30 91 114WELCOME National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 20223Now that the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program is in its fourth decade, we know that now is the time to come together as a community to end the HIV epidemic in the U.S. HRSA continues to move forward with the federal Ending the HIV Epidemic in the U.S. (EHE) initiative. To achieve the goals of the EHE initiative, HAB understands we must continue to promote health equity to reduce HIV-related health disparities; be innovative in how we deliver HIV care and treatment and support services to people with HIV; and ensure that people with HIV and their communities are involved in the planning, development, and implementation of HIV care and treatment service delivery. HRSA's HIV/AIDS Bureau hosts the NRWC every two years to deliver program and policy updates, share innovative models of care, and provide training and technical assistance to Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program recipients; federal, national, state, and local stakeholders; health care and service delivery providers; and people with HIV. This biennial event provides a forum to share best practices and innovative strategies that will help participants continue to implement a coordinated national response to reduce new HIV infections and HIV-related health disparities. I am especially looking forward to the 2022 NRWC this year because we will have the opportunity to highlight the incredible work of the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program, including all of our recipients and partners. I hope your participation in the 2022 NRWC will be rewarding. The 2022 NRWC offers a time for reflection of the past two years and an opportunity to highlight our collective resiliency as well as provide a productive exchange of valuable knowledge and information. Thank you for your commitment to providing high quality, comprehensive care and treatment to people with HIV and your efforts to end the HIV epidemic in the United States. Sincerely, Laura Cheever, M.D., Sc.M. Associate Administrator, HRSA HIV/AIDS BureauDear Colleague: On of the Health Resources and Services Administration's (HRSA) HIV/AIDS Bureau (HAB), I look forward to your participation in the virtual 2022 National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment (2022 NRWC) on August 23-26, 2022. The 2022 NRWC theme is "The Time Is Now: Harnessing the Power of Innovation, Health Equity, and Community to End the HIV Epidemic." WELCOME National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 20224Over the past two years, I have been reminded of so many parallels between the beginning of AIDS and the beginning of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) epidemic. We thought in the beginning that HIV would not be around for very long. Many people thought the COVID-19 shut downs would last a couple of weeks. Before all the science on AIDS was out there - people believed it was airborne. At one of Ryan's first court hearings on attending school, a doctor testified that he would not let his children go to school with Ryan because Ryan had been diagnosed with AIDS. Thankfully, AIDS did not end up to be transmitted airborne. It has been wonderful to see the public health impact of education in the fight against COVID-19. COVID-19 has raised awareness about viruses. People used to be more complacent about their health. COVID-19 has been a wakeup call. People have become more aware by driving home the COVID-19 public health message that you have to be responsible for your own health. I want to stress the importance in continuing to talk about HIV. The recent advertisements introducing people on PrEP and HIV medications have raised the public's awareness. We need to continue to drive home the message to the general public on the importance of empowering communities to end the HIV epidemic. Educate about the risks, treatment that is available and taking responsibility for personal actions. We need to continue to get the message out that zero detectable is non-transmittable. Ryan used to say, "We have to talk about sex, drugs and sexuality." He loved talking to kids and young adults because he felt they listened and were receptive to the message. When Senator Edward Kennedy called in 1990 to say they'd like to name the CARE Act after Ryan, we didn't think it would end up saving so many lives for so many years. I want to thank you for all you do daily to help people with HIV. Your continued good work makes all the difference! I am always so thrilled to attend this conference and to meet the people who dedicate themselves to fighting the HIV epidemic on the front lines. And, I know Ryan White would be proud of you all too! Sincerely, Jeanne White-GinderDear Attendees: Welcome to the 2022 National Ryan White HIV Care & Treatment Conference with the theme "The Time is Now: Harnessing the Power of Innovation, Health Equity and Community to End the HIV Epidemic." National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 20225 2022 CONFERENCE THEME & GOALSHRSA's Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program (RWHAP) was named for a courageous young man who was diagnosed with AIDS in December 1984, when he was 13 years old and living in Kokomo, Indiana. He was given six months to live. When he tried to return to school, he fought AIDS-related discrimination. Along with his mother, Jeanne White- Ginder, Ryan White rallied for his right to attend school, gained national attention, and became the face of AIDS. Surprising his doctors, Ryan White lived five years longer than predicted. He died in April 1990, one month before his high school graduation and only months before Congress passed the legislation bearing his name in August 1990: the Ryan White Comprehensive AIDS Resources Emergency (CARE) Act. The theme of the 2022 National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment is The Time is Now: Harnessing the Power of Innovation, Health Equity, and Community to End the HIV Epidemic. This theme reflects the urgency for ending the HIV epidemic in the U.S., while also highlighting the tools and resources we need to accomplish this goal. HRSA's Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program understands we must continue to promote health equity to reduce HIV-related health disparities; be innovative in how we deliver HIV care and treatment, support people with HIV; and ensure people with HIV and their communities are involved in the planning, development, and implementation of HIV care and treatment strategies. healthcare and service delivery providers.Bringing Together Those Who Live Out Ryan White's Legacy Each and Every Day Breaking Down Barriers Transitioning from in person to a virtual conference in 2022 is an opportunity to break down barriers and allows the NRWC's programming to reach more people than ever before. While HRSA's Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program misses seeing our recipients and stakeholders in person, the NRWC is expected to break record attendance in 2022. In 2020, more than 7,000 attendees tuned into the online platform over the course of the conference dates. This year, that number is even larger. National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022 10CONFERENCE WORKSHOP TRACKS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202211 POPULATION-BASED APPROACHES FOR IMPROVING ACCESS, ENGAGEMENT/ REENGAGEMENT, AND HEALTH OUTCOMES This track will focus on novel approaches used to increase access to care and treatment and improve engagement/reengagement in care and treatment for people with HIV. DATA UTILIZATION This track will examine data integration, data analysis, and data utilization with a focus on how these activities enhance engagement/reengagement, service delivery, and public health approaches to ending the HIV epidemic and curing hepatitis C in the RWHAP. INNOVATIVE SYSTEM-LEVEL MODELS FOR HIV SERVICE DELIVERY This track will highlight innovative models of care, system- level enhancements, and workforce development that leads to improvements in health outcomes as well as related co-morbidities, such as hepatitis C, behavioral health, and substance use disorders. CONFERENCE WORKSHOP TRACKS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202212CLINICAL QUALITY MANAGEMENT This track will examine the fundamentals, best practices, and innovations for clinical quality management programs to measure and improve HIV service delivery and health outcomes to reduce health disparities and end the HIV epidemic. RWHAP PLANNING AND RESOURCE ALLOCATION: COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIPS This track will focus on requirements and best practices for integrated planning, program implementation, workforce development, and resource allocation and utilization, including examples of collaborative partnerships and community engagement initiatives that result in a quality, comprehensive system of HIV prevention, care, and treatment that will promote the EHE goals. RWHAP FISCAL AND GRANT MANAGEMENT BOOT CAMP This track focuses on technical assistance training for RWHAP recipients and subrecipients on fiscal and grant management requirements and highlights innovation and best practices. York, DDS, MAS, Professor, Department of Community Health Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey School of Dental Medicine Larry Zayas Rivera, Translucent Project Manager, Centro Ararat Harold Phillips, MRP, Director, White House Office of National AIDS Policy*All times are in Eastern Time FRIDAY, AUGUST 26 1:45 - 2:55 PM Closing Plenary: InnovationPLENARY SPEAKERS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202215 *Bios appear in alphabetical orderCLOVER BARNES Ms. Clover Barnes is a nurse executive with over 20 years of combined experience in healthcare and public health. A champion for health equity, diversity, and inclusion, Ms. Barnes has a demonstrated track record of engaging staff and facilitating change while promoting an organizational culture that supports innovation, collaboration, and data driven decision-making. For the past seven years, Ms. Barnes served as the Bureau Chief of the Care and Treatment Division of the HIV/AIDS, Hepatitis, STD, and TB Administration (HAHSTA), where she provided excellent leadership and administrative oversight of the Ryan White Program and DC Health's Ending the HIV Epidemic Initiatives. In late 2021, Ms. Barnes was appointed to the position of Senior Deputy Director of HAHSTA. Prior to joining DC Health, Ms. Barnes served in a myriad of healthcare administration/ nursing positions in her career including serving as Staff/Charge nurse, Clinic Coordinator, Nursing Manager, Ambulatory Manager, and Chief Operating Officer. Ms. Barnes received her Bachelor of Science in Nursing degree from Milwaukee School of Engineering (MSOE) in Milwaukee, Wisconsin and a Master of Business Administration from University of Phoenix in Phoenix, Arizona. Ms. Barnes has a passion for working with the underserved and invests her time and energy in improving the community in which she lives. Senior Deputy Director, District of Columbia Health Department CHRISSY ABRAHMS WOODLAND Director, Division of Metropolitan HIV/AIDS Programs, HIV/AIDS Bureau, Health Resources and Services Administration Chrissy Abrahms Woodland joined HRSA's HIV/AIDS Bureau (HAB) 17 years ago. During her time in HAB, she worked in Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program Parts A, C, and D while serving in many roles from Project Officer, Deputy Branch Chief, Senior Policy Advisor, Deputy Director, to her current position as Director of the Division of Metropolitan HIV/AIDS Programs. Chrissy is responsible for leading both the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program Part A, which provides assistance to 52 eligible metropolitan areas and transitional grant areas that are most severely impacted by the HIV epidemic, and the Ending the HIV Epidemic in the U.S. initiative for the 39 geographic focus areas within Part A jurisdictions. Chrissy is a graduate of Howard University with a B.S. in Health Sciences. PLENARY SPEAKERS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202216 *Bios appear in alphabetical orderXAVIER BECERRA Xavier Becerra is the 25th Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services and the first Latino to hold the office in the history of the United States. Secretary Becerra served 12 terms in Congress as a member of the U.S. House of Representatives, and during his tenure, he was the first Latino to serve as a member of the powerful Committee on Ways and Means, he served as Chairman of his party's caucus, and as the Ranking Member of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Social Security and Ranking Member of the Subcommittee on Health. Secretary Becerra also served as Attorney General of the state of California, the first Latino to do so. In this role he helped promote competition by taking on a number of pharmaceutical companies that restricted competition through "pay-for-delay" schemes, held several companies accountable for legal violations for not protecting patients' health information, and took action early in the pandemic to keep Californians safe. Born in Sacramento, Secretary Becerra was the first in his family to receive a four- year degree, earning his Bachelor of Arts in Economics from Stanford University. He earned his Juris Doctorate from Stanford Law School. Secretary, Department of Health and Human Services LAURA CHEEVER, MD, SCM Laura W. Cheever, MD, ScM, is the Associate Administrator of the HIV/AIDS Bureau at HRSA. Dr. Cheever previously served as the deputy associate administrator and chief medical officer of the HIV/AIDS Bureau, responsible for leading the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program and HRSA's programming for the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief. She has also provided national leadership for HIV/AIDS care and treatment, including the development of federal guidelines for HIV care. Dr. Cheever joined HRSA in 1999 as the chief of the HIV Education Branch where she was responsible for providing HIV/AIDS clinical education and training for the nation's health care providers. Before joining HRSA, Dr. Cheever was an assistant professor of medicine at Johns Hopkins University. She is committed to serving the HIV population and volunteers at the Bartlett Clinic for HIV Care at the Johns Hopkins University Hospital. Dr. Cheever received her medical degree from Brown University and is board certified in infectious diseases. Dázon is Founder and President of SisterLove, Inc. established in 1989, the first women's HIV, Sexual and Reproductive Justice organization in the southeastern United States. She is a proud member of In Our Own Voice: National Black Women's Reproductive Justice Agenda Partnership, where she advocates for sexual and reproductive health, rights and justice in public health and prevention policies and programs. Dr. Diallo is a co-chair for the Act Now End AIDS National Coalition. She is a member of several bodies of influence including the Women-At-Risk Subcommittee and the Scientific Advisory Group of the HIV Prevention Trials Network, UNFPA Global Advisory Council, the Women's Research Initiative (WRI) and a founding member of SisterSong Reproductive Justice Collective. In 2020, Diallo was appointed to the IAPAC-Lancet HIV Commission on the Future of Urban HIV Response. She is the creator and convener of the Prevention Options for Women Advocacy & Research (POWAR) Partnership and WomenNOW! Institute for SRHRJ for Girls & Women of African Descent worldwide. She has achieved a deep reach with a diverse community of listeners for 28 years, as producer and host of a weekly radio program focused on black women, called "Sisters' Time/WomenSpeak" on WRFG 89.3FM in Atlanta and wrfg.org. Dr. Diallo holds a master's degree in public health from the University of Alabama at Birmingham (C'97) and bachelor's degree from Spelman College (C'86) in Atlanta. In 2012, Dr. Diallo had the distinct honor to receive an honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from her alma mater, Spelman College. MATIFADZA HLATSHWAYO DAVIS, MD, MPH Director of Health, City of St. LouisPLENARY SPEAKERS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202221 *Bios appear in alphabetical orderCAROLE JOHNSON Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) Carole Johnson is the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration, the federal agency in the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services focused on health equity, supporting health care services for historically underserved communities, and working to build a robust and diverse health care workforce. Johnson joined HRSA from the White House COVID-19 Response Team where she led mitigation and surge response efforts. She previously served as Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Human Services, leading the state's largest agency and providing health care and social services to one-in-five New Jerseyans. During her tenure, she expanded Medicaid coverage of mental health and substance use disorder services, created new Medicaid benefits to improve maternal health outcomes, substantially increased child care rates for the first time in a decade, and expanded food assistance benefits. She also served for more than five years in the Obama White House, working on implementation of the Affordable Care Act, combatting the opioid epidemic, responding to public health challenges like Ebola and Zika, and advancing public health priorities. Johnson spent several years on Capitol Hill as health staff. She previously was a program officer with the Pew Charitable Trusts. Heather Hauck is the Deputy Associate Administrator, HIV/AIDS Bureau (HAB), Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) where she provides leadership, technical expertise, and resources for the administration of the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program and the Ending the HIV Epidemic in the U.S. Initiative. Ms. Hauck was formerly the Director of the Maryland Department of Health Infectious Disease and Environmental Health Administration (IDEHA). Prior to the Maryland Department of Health, Ms. Hauck served as the Section Chief, New Hampshire DHHS Division of Public Health, STD/HIV Section in Concord, NH. Before her work in New Hampshire, Ms. Hauck was a co-director and a social worker in the Washington Hospital Center Social Work Department in Washington, D.C.HEATHER L. Johnson's career includes serving as the Vice President of Policy and Advocacy at AIDS United, Associate Executive Director for policy at GMHC, and New Yok City's first Citywide Coordinator for AIDS Policy. PLENARY SPEAKERS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202223 *Bios appear in alphabetical order Venita is the Co-executive director of the Positive Women's Network-USA, a national membership organization for women living with HIV. Venita served as the public policy manager for a federally qualified health center in Houston, TX, where she monitored HIV related health policy and managed an advocacy training program for people living with HIV. In 2016, Venita led a citywide effort to end the HIV epidemic in Houston and drafted the Roadmap to Ending the HIV Epidemic in Houston. Venita has led anti criminalization efforts in Texas defeating an effort to allow HIV test results to be subpoenaed in criminal prosecutions and defeated attempts to introduce new HIV criminalization legislation. Venita was diagnosed with HIV in 2003 and is deeply committed to equity, racial justice and developing the leadership and meaningful involvement of people living with HIV in all decisions that impact the HIV community. VENITA RAY Co-Executive Director, Positive Women's Network-USA HAROLD J. PHILLIPS, MRP Director, White House Office of National AIDS Policy Harold J. Phillips is Director of the White House Office of National AIDS Policy (ONAP). In this position, he leads the effort to set the Biden Administration's domestic HIV/AIDS priorities. He works to ensure the nation's HIV response is accelerated, comprehensive and reflective of the lived experiences of those at risk of and living with HIV. This work is done to reduce the number of new HIV transmissions, improve the quality of life for people with HIV and end the HIV epidemic. Prior to joining the White House, Mr. Phillips served as the Chief Operating Officer for the Ending the HIV Epidemic Initiative in the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Mr. Phillips held prior positions at HRSA's HIV/AIDS Bureau (HAB). His work there included serving as Office Director for the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program (RWHAP) AIDS Education and Training Centers (AETC), Special Projects of National Significance (SPNS) and HAB's work funded by the U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). He was the Deputy Director of the RWHAP Part B and AIDS Drug Assistance Programs (ADAP), and worked with RWHAP recipients, planning councils, providers and consumers. He has a Master's degree in urban and regional planning from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, an undergraduate degree from Kalamazoo College in Michigan and is a person living with HIV. PLENARY SPEAKERS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202224 *Bios appear in alphabetical order Dr. Stacy W. Smallwood is an associate professor of community health in the Jiann-Ping Hsu College of Public Health and affiliate faculty in the Women's, Gender, & Sexuality Studies program at Georgia Southern University. Dr. Smallwood's graduate instruction is in health promotion, education, and behavior, and his specialized training is in the area of HIV/ AIDS prevention. His research focuses on promoting equity in health and well-being among marginalized communities. He believes that scholarship and activism should work together to promote empowerment. His interests include HIV prevention, sexual health, LGBT health, discrimination and health, and community engagement and organizing within marginalized communities. In particular, he is interested in the effects of psychosocial and structural factors on HIV risk among sexual minority people of color. He also consults with community-based HIV prevention organizations on the evaluation of their evidence-based interventions. He is a past chair of the HIV/AIDS Section for the American Public Health Association, and is currently the chair of the Statesboro Commission on Diversity and Inclusion (One Boro Commission). Chris Redwood, Kelli Bench to Bedside: Integrating Anal Cancer Screening for People with HIV in Light of the ANCHOR Study Description: Hear a summary of the results of the Anal Cancer/HSIL Outcomes Research (ANCHOR) Anal Cancer Prevention Study, which ended in September 2021 due to the primary scientific question being answered. In sum, active treatment of HSIL or high- grade squamous intraepithelial lesions in adults with HIV over 35 years old helps to prevent anal cancer, and the study sponsors and ANCHOR investigators recommend this as a standard of care for people with HIV who have HSIL. The presentation of study results will be followed by a panel discussion on the challenges of implementing these study results at the outpatient clinical level and the logistics required to ensure equitable access to HSIL screening and treatment for underserved communities. Learning Objectives: Determine the steps needed to apply ANCHOR study results to your area of service. Identify access barriers anal cancer/ HSIL screening services in your area of service. Explain to local patients and providers the importance of anal cancer screening as part of regular care. Learn how the HHS, OIDP applied this approach to develop the "I Am a Work of ART" viral suppression campaign, which supports Goal 3 of the National HIV/AIDS Strategy. Author (s): Tamara Henry, Tasneem Islam Abstract ID: 20516 Title: Data Tools and Best Practices for Continuity of Services Description : This oral workshop will discuss methods to implement data tools and best practices for continued client enrollment in RWHAP Part B. The presentation will include the steps that are being taken to make data driven decisions to improve patients' access, engagement and health outcomes across our care continuum. Author (s): LaCandria Churchill, Jimmy Llaque Abstract ID: 20522 Title: Implementation of a telePrEP Program in Partnership with State and Local Health Departments in South Carolina Description : Telehealth has the potential to reach individuals in rural areas at risk of HIV acquisition. Through a 12-month clinical telePrEP program conducted in partnership with the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, evaluation of the feasibility and acceptability of PrEP delivered through a telehealth model are explored. Author (s): Marty Player, Nicole Cooper, Darin King, Vanessa Diaz POSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202293Abstract ID: 20524 Title: Expanding Mobile EHE HIV Interventions for COVID-19 Vaccination and STD/HCV Testing for PWID in Baltimore Description : People experiencing substance use/homeless are at increased risk for communicable diseases including HIV, HCV, STIs and COVID-19. With an established Syringe Support Program (SSP), pop up mobile clinics were created in partnership with academic organizations to provide one stop STI/HCV/HIV testing and COVID-19 vaccination. Author (s): Victoria Cargill, Omeid Heidari, Katie O'Conor, Kelly Lowensen, Jess Derrick Hunt, Lisa Parker, Jason Farley Abstract ID: 20528 Title : Innovative approaches for risk-based assessment to increase STI screening for people with HIV Description : The steady rise of bacterial sexually transmitted infections (STIs) in the United States demonstrate the need for new approaches to increase testing of at-risk individuals with HIV to prevent and treat STIs. This study introduced screening protocols to identify more opportunities for testing at multiple sites and in asymptomatic individuals. Author (s): Sophia Salem, Alvina Chu, Rual Pino Abstract ID: 20536 Title : Assessing Medication Access Barriers in Patients with HIV Description : People with HIV experience unpredictable medication access barriers. At the University of Virginia Ryan White Clinic, patients can receive emergency medication supplies if no timely access is secured. This quality improvement project identified the most common access barriers and led to reduction in utility of emergency medication resources. Author(s): Hiba Alzouby, Lindsey Buscemi Abstract ID: 20538 Title : The Best Practices Compilation: Accelerating RWHAP Knowledge Transfer Description : Improving HIV care continuum outcomes requires RWHAP funded organizations to share knowledge and promote "what works" in HIV care. The Best Practices Compilation (targethiv.org/bestpractices) allows organizations to submit information about their interventions and to search and identify interventions that may work for them. Author (s): Natha Bakayoko, Demetrios Abstract ID: 20554 Title : Assessing Need for Primary Care Services at a Needle Exchange Program: Safe Recovery Description : Syringe exchange programs (SEPs) are gradually augmenting their role as a primary health care centers. Health care from SEPs are found to be better accessible by people who inject drugs.The aim of this project is to determine the feasibility of integrating primary care services into syringe exchange programs. Author (s): Catherine HinojosaPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202294Abstract ID: 20558 Title: Impact of a Bilingual COVID-19 Vaccination Campaign in People with HIV Description : COVID-19 vaccination is especially important in people with HIV. We contacted patients in their preferred language in an attempt to increase COVID-19 vaccination rates. After language-specific outreach, we saw a high rate of vaccine uptake in the Spanish- speaking patients (81%) compared to English-speaking patients (4%). Author (s): Anna Jacobs, Mindy Sampson, Leigh Medaris, Jacob Schulte, Joseph Erato, Christopher Polk Abstract ID: 20561 Title: Improving access to HIV care for historically marginalized communities - the National Clinician Consultation Center Model Description : Persons who are incarcerated or homeless have limited access to traditional models of HIV specialty care, and may experience worse HIV-related outcomes as a result. The NCCC provides free, point-of-care teleconsultation for all clinicians and is a valuable tool for expanding access to expert HIV care for these communities Author (s): Carolyn Chu, April Nakayoshi Abstract ID: 20596 Title: Leveraging a Data to Care Approach to Treat Hepatitis C Coinfection in Orange County, Florida Description : Improving collaboration between HCV and HIV surveillance systems with clinical data systems in the RWHAP clinic at the Florida Department of Health in Orange County to help identify, link, and retain in care; hence, leading to HIV viral suppression and cure of HCV. Author (s): Javier Pineiro, Alvina Chu, Merceditas Villanueva Abstract ID: 20635 Title: Not in Care - An Exploratory Analysis of Who and Why Description : Those not retained in RWHAP care are important for care expansion/quality improvement. Those retained in care and not retained in care were compared using 2019 CAREWare data. Substantial number of participants were not retained in care and a large proportion of those not in care have concerning health outcomes. Author (s): Amit Chattopadhyay, Victoria Cargill Abstract ID: 20636 Title: Navigating HIV services for Deaf, Hard of Hearing, and DeafBlind Description : Deaf People Living with HIV (DPLWH) face unique challenges in accessing care for HIV due to language deprivation, lack of resources in ASL, and having consistent qualified interpreters available in clinics. This session will discuss the barriers to care for DPLWH and best practices for engaging DPLWH and providing culturally relevant HIV services. Author (s): Sheyonna Watson, Nicole GainesPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202295Abstract ID: 20652 Title: Corrections and community for continuity of HIV care upon re-entry Description : Care continuity for persons re-entering the community from incarceration is critical for EHE. BCHD linked with Corrections Department to develop referral processes in their SOAR program. Though referrals prior to release had higher rate of first appointments within 30-days, challenges for linkage to care through SOAR remain after release. Author (s): Victoria Cargill, Amit Chattopadhyay, Ricky Moyd, Jr. Abstract ID: 20660 Title: A Multi-faceted, Iterative Program to Increase COVID-19 Vaccine Uptake in a Midwestern HIV Clinic Description : The National Institutes of Health Office of AIDS Research recommend that patients with HIV be prioritized for COVID-19 vaccination. Our vaccine task force addressed barriers and tracked COVID-19 vaccine completion rates in the HIV clinic, leading to high rate of COVID-19 vaccination uptake. Author (s): Samantha Jones, Rachelle Carr, Nichole Regan, Nada Fadul, Abstract ID: 20709 Title: Impact of Covid-19 Protocols on Recruitment for an Engagement in Care Program for Returning Citizens Description : To understand recruitment challenges faced by an HIV engagement in care project for Black women, AFC conducted an exploratory study incorporating constructs from the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research. The main source of recruitment barriers were protocol changes implemented to minimize COVID-19 risk. Implications for future program design are included. Author (s): Andrea Dakin, Nora Bouacha Abstract ID: 20735 Title: Addressing and Identifying Food Insecurity in a Southeastern Ryan White Clinic Description : This presentation describes an intervention to identify, characterize, and mitigate food insecurity in a Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program-eligible population in a Southeastern U.S. clinic. Ongoing assessments and interventions are planned to attenuate food insecurity. The association with viral suppression and retention in care will be examined. Author (s): Lara Valerio, Alexia Williams, Amy Durr, Claire FarelPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202296Abstract ID: 20743 Title: Preliminary Results from a Text Messaging Outreach Initiative to Reengage People Lost to HIV Care Description : Phone call outreach used for patient re-engagement strains limited sources in RWHAP funded outpatient clinic settings. This presentation highlights preliminary results from an ongoing RWHAP clinic initiative to use text messaging as a re-engagement strategy to bring lost patients back to care. Author (s): Afiba Agovi, Meng Pan, ID: 20747 Title: Staff in Ryan White Centers Demonstrate Improved Awareness Related to PrEP Description : Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is crucial for ending the HIV epidemic, yet it is underutilized by people at risk for HIV. Some of the barriers to PrEP may be due to a lack of prescriber awareness. RWHAP funding may partially contribute to an environment of increased PrEP awareness. Author (s): Sharen McKay, 20775 Title: Multilevel Facilitators and Barriers to Cervical Cancer Screening in Women with HIV: A Qualitative Study Description : This poster presentation will provide an overview of barriers and facilitators to Pap test utilization for women with HIV who receive RWHAP Part D services. Using the Socio-Ecological Model, the individual, interpersonal, community, and healthcare system level barriers and facilitators are explored. Author (s): Jennifer McGee-Avila, Michelle Doose, Jacinta Elijah, Erica Williams, Heidi Peijia Zha, Jennifer Tsui Abstract ID: 20777 Title: The Role of Peer Support Specialists within the Continuum of Services for Sexually Transmitted Infections Description : This poster presentation highlights the utilization of a peer support specialist to increase routine bacterial sexually transmitted infection screening, testing, and treatment in an urban clinic and the related patient care outcomes Author (s): Megan Ware-PressleyPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202297Abstract ID: 20780 Title: Advancing the NHAS and EHE Plan: Nurses have Unique Roles Description : The NHAS and EHE focus on undetectable viral load as a strategy to meet goals. To reach and sustain an undetectable viral load, the totality of an individual's life must be supported, often by addressing the social determinates of health impacting them. Nurses have a unique role in identifying and addressing these barriers. Author (s): Donna Sabatino, Evaluating HIV Telehealth Care Description : This poster focuses on the Checklist for Evaluating HIV Telehealth Care. The purpose of the checklist is to assist HIV providers in New York State in assessing the quality of their telehealth services. The poster outlines the rationale and methodology for developing the checklist and steps for implementing the checklist. Author (s): Nova West, Daniel Belanger, Zeenath Rehana Abstract ID: 20819 Title: Peer Educators at Two Universities Leverage Technology to Cultivate Conversations About HIV Testing and Prevention Description : Student health centers collaborated with community partners including the Northeast/Caribbean AIDS Education and Training Center to equip peer educators with information and skills to interview expert HIV providers. The live interviews expanded student HIV knowledge in a relatable way. Project outcomes demonstrated increased HIV testing and ongoing "vodcast" viewing. Author (s): Debbie Cestaro-Seifer, Rachel Fenske Abstract ID: 20834 Title: Implementation of Addressing Barriers to HIV Care via Smart Phones Description : AFC has launched this innovative, system-wide method for clients to communicate with their RWHAP case manager and service providers in Chicago/surrounding counties. This presentation will outline the rationale of why cell phones are important during this pandemic, implementational strategies, and overall health for social and medical needs being met. Author (s): Emily Moreno, Angela Jordan Abstract ID: 20837 Title: Using Online Support to Connect People with HIV to Care and Improve Outcomes Description : The poster will present Positive People, a social platform develop in colalboration between RWHAP recipient Matthew 25 (Kentucky & Southern Indiana), Lifia Corporation, and Syracuse University. The platform is growing organically, helping to reach a broader community, and enables continuing design to improve outcomes for participants. Author (s): Cyndee Burton, Joshua Introne, Clarke Anderson, Steven KarpelesPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202298Abstract ID: 20885 Title: The Max Clinic: A Multi-agency Collaborative Approach to Addressing the Complex Health and Social Needs of People with HIV in Tacoma, WA. Description : The Max Clinic is a multi-agency partnership that exists to address the complex medical and social needs of people with HIV by utilizing a multidisciplinary approach involving case management, field work, and comprehensive medical services to reach people with HIV who are not currently engaged in HIV care. Author (s): Shauna Applin, Health Navigators to Improve Care and Treatment for Black Women Living with HIV Description : The Institute of Women & Ethnic Studies (IWES) and Priority Health Care (PHC) intentionally position peer health navigators at the center of their evidence-informed strategy to improve HIV care and treatment for cisgender and transgender Black women living with HIV in the Greater New Orleans region. Author (s): Jakevia Green, Priya Lewis Abstract ID: 20900 Title: Underserved, Unhoused, and Unequipped: Assisting Young Black Men who have Sex with Men during COVID-19 Description : This poster shows how Health Care Navigators (HCN) find, deliver, and liaise for housing resources for young black men who have sex with men (YBMSM) during COVID-19. We discuss how HCN connect with community partners that provide resources to meet needs of YBMSM, including housing, for an effective delivery. Author (s): Brian Goings, Heather Parnell, Abstract ID: 20905 Title: Attitudes Towards Rapid Start of Antiretroviral Therapy in New Jersey Description : Rapid start of ART has many benefits. In New Jersey, among 69 providers, same-day medical appointments (67%) and rapid start was available (63%). Extended office hours were available at 44% of sites. Providers were least comfortable initiating rapid start for patients with untreated mental illness (38%) or use of illicit drugs (50%). Author (s): Debbie Mohammed, Sunny Choe, Russell Brewer, Jason LeiderPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 202299Data Utilization Abstract ID: 20158 Title: Trends, Patterns, and Factors Associated with HIV Coinfection Among Male Syphilis Cases, 2014-2019, Hawaii Description : By cross matching registries of HIV and other sexually transmitted infections, this study found 27.1% of male syphilis cases were coinfected with HIV and 31.8% of those coinfected were not virally suppressed. This suggests ongoing sexual risk behaviors and the potential for HIV transmission among male syphilis cases. Author (s): Fenfang Li, Timothy J McCormick, Alan R Katz, Alan Komeya, Katherine Sung, Gerald Hasty, Glenn M Wasserman Abstract ID: 20427 Title: Service Use Variation and Associations with Viral Suppression: Five Years of Minneapolis-St. Paul TGA Data Description : We analyzed variation in service use and associations between service use and viral suppression by race/ethnicity. Results can be used to identify areas for potential quality improvement. Author (s): Eva Enns, Aaron Peterson, Margo Wheatley, Julian Thomas Blissett Abstract ID: 20523 Title: Electronic Medical Record (EMR) Data Collection and Infrastructure Improvement Description : Positive Health Clinic successfully completed a quality improvement project related to our EMR, EPIC. The focus of this project was streamlining data collection, data utilization, and reporting processes in the EMR. The enhancements to our EMR yielded improvements in three areas: communication across disciplines, formalized treatment plans, and data reporting. Author (s): Samantha McGraw, Christina Griffin Abstract ID: 20540 Title: Importing Epic Report Data into CAREWare using the CAREWare PDI Facility Description : Utilizing Epic's reporting tools and the CAREWare Provider Data Import (PDI) will allow sites to realize significant reduction in staff effort required for data entry every month. Author (s): Kevin Faaborg, Maja SaracPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022100Abstract ID: 20553 Title: Strengthening the Safety Net: Testing a Data-to-suppression (D2S) Intervention in the RWHAP Description : We will describe the development, early implementation, and simultaneous stepped-wedge evaluation of a novel structural intervention to promote viral suppression and reduce health disparities. The "data-to-suppression (D2S)" intervention involves enhanced Health Department data sharing and capacity building with providers of RWPA mental health, harm reduction, supportive counseling, and housing services. Author (s): Mary Irvine, Faisal Abdelqader, Jacinthe Thomas, Jennifer 20557 Title: Cancer Mortality in New Jersey, 2000-2018 Description : Cancer-related mortality accounted for 10% of deaths among PWDH, in New Jersey from 2000-2018. The most common cancers were non-Hodgkins Lymphoma (ADC) and lung cancer (non-ADC), ranked as number 1 and 2, followed by of colo-rectal, liver cancer, and KS, in 2015 to 2018. Author (s): Debbie Mohammed Abstract ID: 20634 Title: Oral Health Data in CAREWare: Process Optimization - the Baltimore EMA Experience Description : Oral health of RWHAP participants remains a critical area of unassessed unmet need. Normative data needs and SWOT analyses indicated need for process improvement strategies involving providers for better data quality. Voluntary oral health data reporting is a key barrier to understanding/tracking the oral health status of RWHAP participants. Author (s): Chattopadhyay, Victoria Cargill Title: Addressing Opiate Use through Practice Transformation: Implementing Dashboard Reports to Improve Panel-Based Care Description : The U.S. opioid epidemic has significant impact on rates of overdose deaths among people with HIV. The aim of the project was to leverage the PDSA methodology to enhance a population-based, health information technology, intervention to facilitate the identification and panel management of high-risk clients with opioid use disorder. Author (s): Mila Gonzalez Davila, Sara Lewittes, Susan Olender, Jesse ThomasPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022101Abstract ID: 20706 Title: The Relationship Between Community and Interpersonal Violence, and HIV Prevalence Among Black women in Dallas, Texas Description : HIV prevalence among Black women is at epidemic levels with violence greatly contributing to this statistic. The application of machine learning to HIV studies has the ability to inform more personalized approaches to decreasing HIV prevalence as well as improve the health outcomes of those people with HIV. Author (s): Kimberly Deas, Thomas Hunt, Terri 20744 Title: Applying Technological Innovation: Harnessing an Electronic Patient Portal to Achieve a Patient-centered Approach to Recertification Description : Using a multidisciplinary approach to harness the electronic patient portal for completion of RWHAP six-month recertification documents, we were able to create a more patient-centered method that complies with program requirements. We will discuss the challenges, opportunities, and results of using such technology in program recertification. Author (s): Jeremy Chow, Gwendolyn Martin, Piper Duarte Abstract ID: 20783 Title: Collecting and Using Data to Inform and Improve Information Dissemination Description : The TargetHIV website is the central hub for RWHAP technical assistance (TA), with an audience of 40,000 unique users a year. Of these, approximately 25 percent access resources from data-related TA providers. This poster will describe how we collect and interpret website data to monitor and improve our dissemination approaches. Author (s): Taylor Crosby, Isia Benson, Nicolé Mandel Abstract ID: 20835 Title: Assessing Programmatic Impact of Movement Between Geographically Clustered Part A Service Areas in Florida Description : RWHAP Part A programs in Florida are housed within county governments, not the state department of health. This prevents direct data sharing, leading to outdated out-of-care (OOC) lists. Migration of residents between counties complicates the management of OOC lists, creating a need for streamlined data exchange and matching. Author(s): Ann Marie Stringer, Karalee Poschman, Ryan Neil, Rachel WinePOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022102Abstract ID: 20859 Title: A Call for Enhanced Data Collection Description : The syndemic of opioid use disorder, HCV and HIV and stigma causes burdens on individuals and the system. Integrating siloed systems of care is critical to addressing this crisis. Overlapping cascades of care are key to understanding the empirical relationships of these diseases and opportunities to identify, prevent and co-treat. Author (s): Anthony Eller, Kimberly Johnson, Elizabeth DiDomizio, Abstract ID: 20877 Title: Two States' Journeys to Integrate Programs and Utilize Innovative Approaches to Improve Data Quality Description : Data Systems are often black holes, where agencies enter in data, but are not able to efficiently access useful and actionable data back out to take actions to improve services. Learn how panel participants are using innovation and participatory design to provide useful tools and data to the front lines. Author (s): Gretchen Regier, Weston Stokely, Laine Snow, Andrew Gans, Jesse Thomas Abstract ID: 20915 Title: Systematic Collaboration - Adapting an In-house Case Management Data System Description : There is a lack of case management products for HIV surveillance programs, many states develop home-grown systems in response. In 2019, Louisiana prioritized upgrading their home-grown case management database - and identified Florida's system as a potential replacement. This presentation will review process of implementing the FL system in LA. Author (s): Ann Marie Stringer, Jessica Fridge, Cortlandt Schoonover, Madison Albright, Hasan MirzaPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022103Innovative System-level Models for HIV Service Delivery Abstract ID: 20455 Title: Telemedicine Implementation at a Midwestern HIV Clinic During COVID-19: One Year Outcomes Description : This HIV clinic evaluated effectiveness of telemedicine for selected patient during the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic, and found overall viral suppression and retention in care rates were not adversely impacted by switch to telemedicine. They also noted similar rates of telemedicine utilization across demographic criteria. Author (s): Nada Fadul, Laura Krajewski Abstract ID: 20499 Title: Promising Practices: The Impact of COVID-19 Related Policy Changes On Enrollment Capacity Within California's ADAP Description : California's AIDS Drug Assistance Program (ADAP) and Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis Assistance Program (PrEP-AP) provide access to life-saving medications and insurance assistance for eligible California residents living with or at risk of acquiring HIV. This presentation will explore the efficacy of various program policy changes implemented by California during the COVID-19 pandemic. Author (s): Genevieve Kray, Ann Nakamura, Kelly Wu Abstract ID: 20555 Title: Maintaining Open Communication in a City without Power: A Communication Model Following Hurricane Ida Description : Following Hurricane Ida in New Orleans, Tulane ID providers utilized an innovative communication model to contact patients using a Google Voice number to act as the clinic call back number. Using this model, 88 out of 132 patients were successfully reached, with 36 percent of those that answered requiring urgent refills. Author (s): Crystal Zheng, Madison Bangert, Erik Meyers, Sree Lanka, Kaylor Wright, Travis Mattingly Abstract ID: 20559 Title: Practice Transformation: Improvements in Outcomes Along the HIV Care Continuum at Clinics in New England Description : This presentation will provide a brief overview of the New England AETC practice transformation project and describe improvements in HIV service delivery and patient outcomes over the past five years at seven clinic sites located in Massachusetts, Connecticut, and Rhode Island. Author (s): Scott Hebert, Vanessa Carson-Sasso, Hathy Simpson, Amanda Hart, Robert Sideleau, Sheela ShenoiPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022104Abstract ID: 20647 Title: Implementing an HIV Ambulatory Curriculum in Internal Medicine Residency Programs Description : The Yale AIDS program developed a three-hour HIV ambulatory workshop for graduate medical education programs. This interactive curriculum showed that it improved the knowledge, skills and attitude of trainees in HIV testing, management, and PrEP. This curriculum has the potential to be dessiminated to other residency programs. Author (s): Robert Sideleau, Lydia Barakat, Sharen McKay Abstract ID: 20651 Title: Development and Implementation of Virtual HIV Clinical Preceptorships During COVID-19 Description : Described is the implementation of a virtual clinical preceptorship protocol piloted at a RWHAP funded clinic in San Antonio, TX by the local AIDS Education Training Center (AETC) program to allow health care professionals to virtually learn about clinical HIV management despite pandemic restrictions. Author (s): Waridibo Allison, Maria Gutierrez, Title: Get READI! Outcomes from Two Years of Rapid ART Services at a County Hospital System Description : Harris Health System began its Rapid Eligibility and ART Dissemination & Implementation (READI) program in 2019. Here, we present two years of data that examine linkage to care, ART initiation, viral loads, completion of medical visits, and demographics for patients who received READI services and those who did not. Author (s): Jennifer Carey Abstract ID: 20698 Title: Improving Routine Sexual Transmitted Infections (STI) Testing Among People with HIV Description : Introduction. In Louisiana, the rates of sexually transmitted infections (STI) rank among the top ten. Approach. A sexual activity history was completed utilizing an audio computer-assisted self-interview tool. Results. Over 40% of the recommended STI screenings were extragenital testing. Discussion. A sexual activity history tool provides reliable recommendations for STI testing. Author (s): Dionne Bell, Eloisa Lopez Abstract ID: 20711 Title: Implementing Medicare Wellness Visits in a RWHAP Clinic Description : People aging with HIV are at increased risk and experience an array of comorbidities including diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and neurocognitive impairment. This poster will demonstrate the implementation of Medicare Wellness Visits, outcome data and lessons learned. Author (s): Kate Codd-PalmerPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022105Abstract ID: 20727 Title: Expanding Access to Substance Use and Mental Health Services for HIV Patients in Alabama Description : The objective of this study is to assess key stakeholders, including patients, for readiness to adopt a new standard of care. Because many people with HIV in Alabama experience low literacy, low income, and are racial minorities, data suggests they will experience greater barriers to healthcare information technology, like PROs and Telehealth. Author (s): Ellen Eaton Abstract ID: 20751 Title: Epidemic through a Pandemic: Strategies to Support Black Women with HIV during COVID-19 Pandemic Description : This poster will provide information about approaches of the Black Women First Initiative in adressing HIV epidemic through the COVID-19 pandemic. Various strategies were developed and adapted by the 12 RWHAP SPNS demonstration sites by changing their existing systems for a more culturally responsive care for Black women with HIV. Author(s): Minu P. Mohan, Cecilia Flores-Rodríguez, Linda Sprague Serena Rajabiun Abstract ID: 20792 Title: Integrating Services for Improved Access to Oral Health Care in People with HIV/AIDS Description : Oral health problems in people with HIV are common and access to oral health care remains inadequate. Co-location of RWHAP and dental clinic improves accessibility. Our study aims to assess the effectiveness of integration of medical and dental services in improving access to oral health care through co-location. Author (s): Shane Cobert, Mary Louise Decker, Satya Upadhyayula ID: 20831 Title: Adapting HIV Service Delivery During COVID-19: Lessons Learned Description : BPHC and HIV service agencies in the Boston EMA quickly adapted during the pandemic by shifting to telehealth, streamlining and enhancing processes, and expanding services to accommodate changing client needs. These changes have led to valuable lessons learned to reduce barriers to care, sustain adaptability and modernize service delivery. Author (s): Katie Keating, Austin Hanna, Fabiola CatullePOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022106Abstract ID: 20843 Title: Telemedicine to Achieve HIV Viral Suppression in Incarcerated People in Tennessee - 9-Year Retrospective (2010 - 2018) Description : In collaboration with Tennessee Department of Corrections, we developed and implemented a stepwise HIV telemedicine program to optimize viral suppression in the state prisons during 2010-2018. Clinic attendance increased from 50 percent to 90 percent during full implementation. Viral suppression increased from 30 percent in 2010 to 90 percent in 2018. Author (s): Vladimir Berthaud, Michael Caldwell, Livette Johnson, Toni Hall Abstract ID: 20914 Title: Our WORK: Women and Infant Supportive Housing Demonstration Project Description : Our Women Organizing Resources and Knowledge (WORK) is supportive housing demonstration project developed to address and reduce gaps in resources for low-income women with HIV with children. Learn best practices and lessons learned through the development and implementation project. Author(s): Evelyn Postell-Franklin, Chunnika HodgesPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022107Clinical Quality Management Abstract ID: 20462 Title: Implementation and Evaluation of a COVID-19 Vaccine Program in a Rural Setting Description : Significant challenges exist in vaccinating people with HIV for COVID-19. Our RWPC program set out to implement and evaluate a vaccine initiative for COVID-19 for people with HIV. We achieved vaccine rates of 78 percent being fully vaccinated by December 1, 2021 and 30 percent having a third dose. Author(s): Anushka David Maximize: A Cadence of Accountability the Key to Optimizing Service Delivery Description: Minimize to Maximize. The Utah RWHAP Part B Program follows Franklin Covey's 4 Disciplines of Execution to collaborate with a medical case management provider to minimize the number of goals to maximize success. A virtual scoreboard monitors measures and commitments within a structured cadence of self-accountability to improve outcomes. Author Provider-led Reproductive Health Visits to Increase Contraception Counseling Among Persons with HIV Description: The percentage of people with HIV who could become pregnant and lacked designated form of contraception rose from 13 percent to 22.5 percent between April 2020-April 2021 in our Southeastern RWHAP clinic. We developed a reproductive health visit to reduce the rate of those with no contraception plan from 22.5 percent to 17 percent by July 2022. Author (s): Emily Duberman, Arianne Morrison, Christopher Abstract ID: 20615 Title: COVID 19 Burnout: Using Continuous Quality Improvement to Support Staff and Improve Job Satisfaction Description: Community Health Awareness Group worked remotely for nearly a year due to COVID-19 and observed staff anxiety as it transitioned to in-person work. A quality project was undertaken using CQI methods to identify and reduce staff burnout. The project proved that the practice of self-care techniques decreased staff stress. Author (s): Christina Abate, Dena HughesPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022108Abstract ID: 20620 Title: Developing, Implementing, and Sustaining Quality Improvement Efforts Within a Network: The Baltimore EMA Description: The Baltimore City Health Department Ryan White Program utilizes a variety of methods to engage stakeholders including program monitoring, technical assistance, and learning opportunities among staff, sub-recipients, and consumers across the Baltimore EMA. The program also leads a cross-network QI team to implement interventions, strengthening its QI efforts. Author (s): Lauren Wagner, Rodrique Sumpter, Joan Carey, Ricky Moyd, Jr., Alberta Lin Ferrari ID: 20642 Title: The Future of Trauma-Informed Care Description: As trauma awareness grows in all aspects of our communities, it is time to ask, "What are the next innovations in helping those with HIV recover from trauma?" This workshop will show how new technology helps to quantify resiliency and post-traumatic growth for patients and clients. Author(s): Matt Bennett, Jeff Somers Abstract and Back: Rethinking Self-care Description: Before the pandemic, HIV providers were among the most burnt-out professions in our society. This workshop helps to identify the dangers to our mental, physical, and social health resulting from the demands our work combined with the exposure to the stress and trauma of our those we serve. Author(s): Matt Bennett Abstract ID: 20649 Title: Let's Talk about the Vicious Cycle of Annual 3 Site STI Screening for MSM Description: A NJ clinic has implemented multi-site STI screening for the clinic population and for higher risk groups. Gains made in implementation through prior quality initiatives were not sustained. The clinic worked collaboratively with a quality coach to identify how and why rectal swabs are overlooked, particularly when indicated. Author(s): Theresa Fox, Sarah CorringtonPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022109Abstract ID: 20774 Title: Quality Management through a Collaborative Learning Process: Virginia Cross Part Collaborative Performance Measures Description: The Virginia Ryan White Part B (RWB) Peer Review Team works in collaboration with 24 subcontractors receiving RWB funding to evaluate qualitative and quantitative service data. Peer Reviewers are experts and provide services for RWHAP in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Author(s): Katrina Comolli, Improving Health Outcomes for PLWH Description: This presentation will share innovative strategies in the creation of a reflective Consumer Advisory Board, HIT HIV. The presentation will showcase quality improvement projects the HIT HIV CAB completed while leveraging technology, social media, consumer feedback, and CQM principles ensuring a community-driven and equitable process toward ending the HIV epidemic. Author(s): Kaitlin Lopez, Brandon BrightPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022110RWHAP Planning and Resource Allocation: Community Engagement and Collaborative Partnerships Abstract ID: 20481 Title: New PrEP Prescribers Through an Online Microlearning Course Description: This presentation will describe PrEP course development, using online microlearning modules that can be completed in 10-15 minutes. Target audience for training is providers interested in offering PrEP but unsure how to start and prescribers wanting to ensure their practice is consistent with current standards of care. Author (s): Jan Stockton, Pamposh Kaul, Mary Beth Donica Abstract ID: Title: A Third-Year Service Learning Rotation Program: Dental Students' Perceptions of Community Engagement Experiences Description: Columbia University College of Dental Medicine has partnered with community partners to implement a dental care delivery system for PLWHA in NYC. A week-long Service Learning Rotation was integrated into the third-year dental student curriculum; data analysis from this pilot year will be used for program quality improvement and modification. Author (s): Carol Housing Stability Among PWH in the NY EMA during COVID-19 Description: The COVID-19 public health emergency (PHE) exacerbated homelessness and housing instability. NY EMA Planning staff worked collaboratively to address homelessness as a driving force of poorer health outcomes for people living with HIV. This presentation will illustrate community planning processes for addressing housing-related barriers among RWHAP consumers during the PHE. Spiegler, Eleonora ID: 20624 Title: Providing Trainings and Technical Assistance to Help Continue and Improve HIV Oral Health Services during COVID-19 Description: Oral health providers rely on continuing education to improve HIV care and services. This session describes how the Arizona AETC partnered with the Los Angeles Area AETC and the UCLA School of Dentistry to assess and respond to special training and technical assistance needs of HIV providers during COVID-19. Author (s): Brittany Nigon, Tom Donohoe, Fariba Younai, Alyssa Guido, Sandra CuevasPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022111Abstract ID: 20625 Title: Using Specialized Training Models as a Pipeline into HIV Care for Minority Serving Providers Description: The AETC ACCESS and IPE programs are designed to engage pre-novice to expert healthcare professionals across disciplines into HIV care and build their capacity for HIV treatment of high need, medically underserved, minority populations. This poster highlights the Northeast/Caribbean AETC's impact on expanding the HIV workforce through these programs. Author (s): Spanish-Speaking Community Advisory Board: Integration and Collaboration in HIV Care and Research Description: The Spanish language community advisory board (SCAB) approach was to create horizontal and vertical community entity linkages and understand the nature of institutional interactions. The SCAB facilitates community involvement in patient care and support to improve implementation and sustainability of the HIV prevention and control strategies. Author (s): Luis Argueta, Guadalupe Morales 20645 Title: Innovating Technical Assistance with Educational Technology Description: NECA AETC has expanded training and TA to address diverse learners and asynchronous educational needs with innovative technology, including the Rise platform, podcasting, mobile apps for clinical guides, MIRO, and Airtable. This presentation will include live demonstrations and interactive activities, highlighting flexible modalities for the COVID-19 pandemic and beyond. Author (s): Marianna Title: Collaboration is Key: Working Together to End the HIV Epidemic (EHE) Description: Joining forces to End the HIV epidemic, the Northeast/Caribbean AIDS Education and Training Center worked across our diverse region to increase access to HIV care and prevention through a community-driven approach. Regional partners throughout our Region II jurisdiction collaborated to strengthen HIV testing, PrEP, viral suppression, and structural competency. Author (s): Catherine Farquharson, Daria Boccher-Lattimore, Karen McKinnonPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022112Abstract ID: 20719 Title: Investigating Needs and Scale-Up Costs for RWHAP-Funded Support Services: Food, Financial, Transportation, and Housing Description: We conducted semi-structured interviews with service providers to investigate current barriers, potential opportunities, estimated costs, and anticipated outcomes of program expansion for food, financial, transportation, and housing support services for RWHAP clients. Author (s): Eva Enns, Margo Wheatley, Katie White, Jonathan Hanft Abstract ID: 20721 Title: Development of a Community Planning and Budget Allocation Tool to Reduce HIV Outcome Disparities Description: We used a data-driven, mixed method approach to develop a community planning and budget tool to inform resource allocation decision-making to achieve health equity in HIV outcomes among RWHAP clients in the Minneapolis-St. Paul Transitional Grant Area. Author( s): Aaron Peterson, Eva Enns, Margo Wheatley, Darin ID: 20752 Title: Digital Health Initiative's Model for Training NYS DOH AIDS Institute Staff during COVID-19 Description: The COVID-19 pandemic propelled digital tools to the forefront of healthcare. New York State Department of Health AIDS Institute Digital Health Initiative (DHI) coordinated digital health trainings to enhance practices among HIV program staff and may result in improved patient-provider communication, patient access to services and potentially health outcomes. Author (s): Mark Thompson, Beatrice Aladin Abstract ID: Example: Northeast/Caribbean AETC during COVID-19 Description: Over the past two years, the HIV workforce was challenged to not only maintain services but to rapidly address COVID-19. This case example of the AETC response, demonstrates Northeast/Caribbean AETC's efforts to rapidly bring needed expertise and resources directly to community providers serving highly impacted communities. Author (s): Nadine Nader, Daria Boccher-Lattimore, Francine Cournos, Karen McKinnonPOSTER PRESENTATIONS National Ryan White Conference on HIV Care & Treatment | 2022113Abstract ID: 20849 Title: Themes from "Equity, Innovation, and Synergy: Building Connections to End the HIV Epidemic" Virtual Convening Description: This session will share findings from the 2021 National Ending the HIV Epidemic (EHE) TA Implementation Meeting. Author (s): Jennifer Flannagan, Krupa Mehta Abstract ID: 20891 Title: Best Practices for Recruitment and Retention of RWHAP Part A Planning Councils/Planning Bodies: Lessons from a Learning Collaborative Description: Planning CHATT will provide an overview of the RWHAP Part A Recruitment and Retention Learning Collaborative, share recruitment and retention strategies, and describe best practices for PC/PBs developing a recruitment and retention plan. People with HIV struggle to access oral health care. Adequate oral health care is especially important for persons living with HIV as they are often predisposed to oral health conditions and diseases such as caries, periodontal disease, oral lesions and xerostomia. Data from HRSA HAB suggest that a majority of people with HIV had not seen a dentist in more than two years. Barriers and lack of access to oral healthcare may significantly impact systemic health along with impacting quality of life. By improving the integration of oral health in primary care some of these oral health barriers can be addressed by (1) detecting disease at an earlier stage, (2) better educating patients on the importance of oral health and (3) connecting patients to dental care providers.
